vi_translation: And so I went. I quietly jumped through the window, and we crouched and ran along the side of the house until we could open the door of the minivan. Margo whispered not to close the car doorâ€”it would make too much noiseâ€”so with the door left open, I didn't start the car but pushed my foot against the cement, letting the car slowly roll down the road. We slowly passed a few houses before I started the engine and turned on the lights. We closed the car door, and I began driving through the seemingly endless winding streets of Jefferson Park, the houses still new and made of plastic, looking like a toy village with tens of thousands of real people.

en: Margo managed to speak in her usual manic soliloquy without answering my question. â€œDid you know that for pretty much the entire history of the human species, the average life span was less than thirty years? You could count on ten years or so of real adulthood, right? There was no planning for retirement. There was no planning for a career. There was no planning. No time for planning. No time for a future. But then the life spans started getting longer, and people started having more and more future, and so they spent more time thinking about it. About the future. And now life has become the future. Every moment of your life is lived for the futureâ€”you go to high school so you can go to college so you can get a good job so you can get a nice house so you can afford to send your kids to college so they can get a good job so they can get a nice house so they can afford to send their kids to college.â€

es_translation: Margo managed to unleash one of her usual frenetic monologues without answering my question. â€”Did you know that, for almost the entire history of the human species, the average lifespan has been less than thirty years? They had about ten years of adult life, right? They didn't plan for retirement. They didn't plan their professional career. They didn't plan anything. They didn't have time to make plans. They didn't have time to think about the future. But then life expectancy started to increase and people began to have more and more future, so they spent more time thinking about it. You live every moment of your life for the futureâ€¦ You go to high school so you can go to college, and that way you can find a good job, and that way you can buy a nice house, and that way you can afford to send your kids to college so they can find a good job and that way they can buy a nice house and that way they can afford to send their kids to college.

tr_translation: Margo, as usual, managed to speak in her crazy monologue without answering my question. â€œDid you know that for almost all of human history, the average lifespan was less than thirty years? Every moment of your life is lived for the future... you go to high school so you can go to college, so you can get a good job, so you can buy a nice house, so you can afford to send your kids to college, so your kids can get a good job, so they can buy a nice house, so they can afford to send their kids to college.â€

vi_translation: Margo responded in a monologue style mixed with a familiar excitement without directly answering my question. "You know, from ancient times and for a very long period in human history, the average lifespan of humans was less than thirty. That means people had about ten years of adulthood, right? So there was no need to plan for retirement. No career planning either. No concept of planning at all. There was no time to plan. No time for the future. But then lifespans started to lengthen, and people began to have more of what we call the future, so they spent more time thinking about it. Thinking about the future. And now life has become the future. Every moment in your life is lived for the futureâ€”you go to high school to get into college to get a good job to buy a nice house to earn money to send your kids to college so they can get good jobs to buy nice houses to earn money to send their kids to college."

vi_translation: Margo gently patted my back. "Didn't I tell you that everything would become clear before dawn?" And then, in the boating equipment section, Margo picked up an air horn. She took it out of the box and raised it high, and I immediately said, "No, don't," and Margo asked back, "What do you mean, don't?" I continued, "You can't use an air horn here," but I had barely said the "u" in "use" when she pressed the horn and a piercing shriek tore through the air, buzzing in my head, as if my blood vessels were swelling and pounding. Margo calmly asked, "Sorry, I didn't hear you, what did you just say?" And I was in the middle of saying "Don't b..." when she pressed the horn again.

Finally the trees stopped and the field opened up, and I could see the parkway on our right and the moat straight ahead of us. People could have seen us from the road if there had been any cars, but there werenâ€™t. Together we took off running through the brush, and then made a sharp turn toward the parkway. Margo said, â€œNow, now!â€ and I dashed across the six lanes of highway. Even though it was empty, something felt exhilarating and wrong about running across a road that big.

es_translation: We ran along International Drive and then made our way through tall bushes and oaks. I started to worry about poison ivy, but ninjas don't worry about those things, so I took the lead, with my arms outstretched, and pushed aside the brambles and weeds as we advanced toward the moat. Eventually, the wooded area ended and we reached an open field. I could see the highway to our right and the moat directly ahead. We could have been seen from the road if any cars had passed by, but none did. We ran through the underbrush and made a sharp turn toward the highway. â€”Now! Now! â€”exclaimed Margo. And I ran across the six lanes of the highway. Although it was empty, crossing such a large road seemed thrilling and inappropriate to me.

vi_translation: We walked through I-Drive, starting to find our way through the dense oaks and tangled bushes. I was a bit worried about the ivy's toxins, but ninjas aren't afraid of ivy toxins, so I charged ahead, arms raised in front of me, pushing the thorny branches aside to move towards the moat. en: So what he did was he took a pencil and one of those steel compass things, and he started drawing circles onto a piece of paper. All the circles exactly two inches in diameter. And he would draw the circles until the entire piece of paper was completely black, and then he would get another piece of paper and draw more circles, and he did this every day, all day, and didnâ€™t pay attention in school and drew circles all over all of his tests and shit, and my mom said that this kidâ€™s problem was that he had created a routine to cope with his loss, only the routine became destructive. So anyway, then my mom made him cry about his dad or whatever and the kid stopped drawing circles and presumably lived happily ever after. But I think about the circles kid sometimes, because I can sort of understand him. I always liked routine. I suppose I never found boredom very boring. I doubted I could explain it to someone like Margo, but drawing circles through life struck me as a kind of reasonable insanity.

es_translation: What the boy did was take a pencil and a compass, and start drawing circles on a sheet of paper. All the circles were exactly five centimeters in diameter. And he drew circles until the entire sheet of paper was completely black. Then he would take another sheet and draw more circles. And he did this every day, all the time. He didn't pay attention in class, he drew circles on all the exams, and my mother told me that the boy's problem was that he had created a routine to cope with his loss, but the routine had become destructive. The fact is that my mother managed to make him cry for his father, and the boy stopped drawing circles and apparently lived happily ever since. But every now and then I think about the boy with the circles, because in some way I understand him. I've always liked routines. I suppose that being bored never really bored me too much. I figured I couldn't explain it to someone like Margo, but spending your life drawing circles seemed like a somewhat reasonable madness to me.

tr_translation: In the end, he did something like this: He took one of those steel compasses with a pencil and started drawing circles on a piece of paper. All the circles were exactly two centimeters in diameter. He would draw circles until the entire paper was black, then take another paper and draw more circles, and he did this continuously every day. He wasn't paying attention in classes and was drawing circles all over his exam papers and such, and my mom said that the child's problem was that the routine he created to cope with his loss had become destructive. So anyway, then my mom made him cry for his father or something, and the kid stopped drawing circles and apparently lived happily ever after. But sometimes I think about the circle kid because I kind of understand him. I've always liked routine. I guess I've never found boredom boring. I wasn't sure if I could explain this to someone like Margo, but in life, drawing circles left me with the impression of a reasonable kind of madness.

vi_translation: And the boy did this, he took a pencil and one of those things like a metal compass, and started drawing circles on paper. All the circles had an exact radius of five centimeters. The boy kept drawing circles until the paper was completely black, then he would take another sheet and continue drawing circles. He did this every day, all day long, not paying attention to his studies, drawing circles all over his tests and schoolwork. My mother said the boy's problem was that he had created a regular habit to cope with loss, but it was this very habit that was destroying him. So when my mother tried to make the boy cry for his lost father, he stopped drawing circles, and was said to live happily ever after from then on. But sometimes I think about that boy drawing circles, because it seems like I understand him. I've always liked regular habits. I even think that I never found boredom to be all that boring. Maybe I can't explain this to someone like Margo, but drawing circles for the rest of my life gives me a bit of a crazy sense of meaning.

en: â€œNo, thanks,â€ I said, and breezed past them through the kitchen and into the garage. I found the widest flathead screwdriver and then stuck it in the waistband of my khaki shorts, cinching my belt tight. I grabbed a cookie out of the kitchen and then walked back through the living room, my gait only slightly awkward, and while they watched the televised mystery unfold, I removed the three pins from my bedroom door. When the last one came off, the door creaked and started to fall, so I swung it all the way open against the wall with one hand, and as I swung it, I saw a tiny piece of paperâ€”about the size of my thumbnailâ€”flutter down from the doorâ€™s top hinge. Typical Margo. Why hide something in her own room when she could hide it in mine? I wondered when sheâ€™d done it, how sheâ€™d gotten in. I couldnâ€™t help but smile.

es_translation: â€”No, thank you â€”I replied. I crossed the kitchen and entered the garage. I looked for the largest flathead screwdriver we had, tucked it into the waistband of my khaki shorts, and tightened my belt. I grabbed a cookie from the kitchen, crossed the living room again with only slightly clumsy steps, and while they watched on TV how the mystery was solved, I removed the three nails from my bedroom door. tr_translation: â€œNo, thanks,â€ I said and breezed past them from the kitchen to the garage. I found the largest flathead screwdriver, then tucked it into the belt of my khaki shorts and tightened my belt. I grabbed a cookie from the kitchen, passed through the living room again, my walking style must have looked slightly odd, and they were engrossed in the unraveling mystery on the television. While they were following the tracks, I removed three hinges from my room's door. When the last one came out, the door creaked and started to fall, so I leaned it against the wall with one hand and fully opened it. As I pushed the door, I saw a tiny piece of paper, roughly the size of my thumbnail, fluttering down from the top hinge of the door. Typical Margo. Why would she hide something in her own room when she could have hidden it in mine? I wondered when she did this... how she got inside. I couldn't help but smile.

vi_translation: "No," I replied, running from the living room through the kitchen, into the garage. I found the largest flathead screwdriver, tucked it into the waistband of my khaki shorts, and tightened my belt. I grabbed a cookie from the kitchen and then went back through the living room to my room, walking a bit awkwardly. While my parents were engrossed in the TV show revealing the mystery of the case, I quietly removed the three screws from the hinge of my room door. When the last one came out, the door made a "crack" sound and loosened. I pushed and pulled the door around the edge of the wall with one hand, and as I did so, I saw a tiny piece of paperâ€”about the size of my thumbnailâ€”fall from the top hinge. Classic Margo. Why hide something in her own room when she could hide it in mine? I wondered when she had done it, and how she had gotten in. I couldn't help but smile.

en: I took a long breath. The excitement of being somewhere other than school had started to wane. This didnâ€™t seem like a place where Margo would hide, or even visit. It was a far cry from New York City. This was the Florida you fly over, wondering why people ever thought to inhabit this peninsula. I stared at the empty asphalt, the heat distorting my vision. Ahead, I saw a strip mall wavering in the bright distance.

en: I unrolled the carpet partway and immediately found something else: a flattened, empty box that had once contained twenty-four nutrition bars. I found myself able to imagine Margo here, leaning against the wall with musty rolled-up carpet for a seat, eating a nutrition bar. She is all alone, with only this to eat. Maybe she drives once a day to a convenience store to buy a sandwich and some Mountain Dew, but most of every day is spent here, on or near this carpet. This image seemed too sad to be trueâ€”it all struck me as so lonely and so very unMargo. But all the evidence of the past ten days accumulated toward a surprising conclusion: Margo herself wasâ€”at least part of the timeâ€”very unMargo.

Too lonely and not at all like Margo. But the clues from the last ten days seemed to lead to a surprising conclusion: Margo was â€”at least a good part of the timeâ€” very unlike Margo.

tr_translation: I partially opened the drawer and found something else inside: a flattened, empty box that once contained twenty-four wafers. I could imagine Margo here, using the moldy carpet as a seat, leaning against the wall, and eating a wafer. Completely alone, with only these wafers as food. Maybe she goes to a market once a day to get a sandwich and a few Mountain Dews, but she spends most of her days here, on or beside this carpet. This vision seemed too pitiful to be real... it struck me that all of this was very lonely and very unMargo-like. But when all the evidence of the last ten days was accumulated, a surprising result emerged: even Margo herself was, at least sometimes, very unMargo-like.

vi_translation: I had spread the carpet halfway when I discovered something else: an empty, flat-folded box that had once contained twenty-four synthetic nutrition bars. I began to imagine Margo had been here, leaning against the wall, sitting on the musty rolled-up carpet, eating a nutrition bar. She was completely alone, with only this to eat. But all the evidence from the past ten days pointed to a surprising conclusion: Margoâ€“at least at timesâ€“was very unlike Margo.

en: But I could also imagine this: Margo picking these books up at various garage sales, buying every travel guide she could get her hands on for a quarter or less. And then coming hereâ€”even before she disappearedâ€”to read the books away from prying eyes. Reading them, trying to decide on destinations. Yes. She would stay on the road and in hiding, a balloon floating through the sky, eating up hundreds of miles a day with the help of a perpetual tailwind. And in this imagining, she was alive. Had she brought me here to give me the clues to piece together an itinerary? Maybe. Of course I was nowhere near an itinerary. Judging from the books, she could be in Jamaica or Namibia, Topeka or Beijing. But I had only just begun to look.

es_translation: But I could also imagine the following: Margo buying those books at various flea markets, buying all the travel guides that fell into her hands at bargain prices. Then going thereâ€”even before she disappearedâ€”to read them away from prying eyes. Reading them and trying to decide where to go. Yes. She would travel and hide, a balloon flying through the sky, covering hundreds of kilometers a day with the help of a perpetual tailwind. And I imagined her alive. Had she brought me there to give me the clues to decipher the itinerary? Maybe. Of course, I was far from having deciphered the itinerary. Judging by the books, she could be in Jamaica, Namibia, Topeka, or Beijing. But I had only just begun to look.

tr_translation: But I could also imagine this: that Margo had randomly found these books from various discount sales and bought all the travel guides she could get her hands on for a quarter or less. Then, even before she disappeared to read these books away from prying eyes, she had come here. Reading them while trying to decide where to go. Yes. She would travel in hiding; then, with the help of a gust of wind, she would cover hundreds of kilometers in a day, floating in the sky like a balloon. And in this dream, Margo was alive. Had she brought me here to give me the clues I needed to piece together a route? Maybe. Of course, I wasn't even close to a route. From what I could gather from the books, she could be in Jamaica, Namibia, Topeka, or Beijing. But I had just started looking.

vi_translation: But I also imagine this: Margo collected these books from various clearance sales, buying any travel guide she could find for under twenty-five cents. Then Margo came hereâ€”even before she disappearedâ€”reading books and staying away from prying eyes. Read them all, trying to map out a journey. Exactly. She would wander without leaving a trace, a balloon drifting in the sky, following the eternal wind, leaving behind hundreds of miles each day. And in this imagination of mine, Margo is full of life. Did Margo lead me here to give me clues to piece together into a journey? Maybe. Of course, so far I haven't even come close to that journey. Based on the books, Margo could be in Jamaica or Namibia, Topeka or Beijing. But I have only just started searching.

vi_translation: I felt Margo's hand on my back. It had already turned dark when I kissed her, but I opened my eyes and so did Margo. She was close enough for me to see her, as there was now an invisible light from within, even in the evening in this parking lot on the outskirts of Agloe. The kiss ended, we pressed our foreheads together and looked at each other. Yes, I could see her almost perfectly in this fractured darkness.
